DOC.HEAD: Group Claiming Mail Bombs Cites Desegregation, Attacks on Whites
With AM-Mail Bombs
DOC.TEXT: The group which has claimed responsibility for the mail bomb deaths of a federal judge and an attorney expressed ire over court rulings in school desegregation cases, an area in which both victims were involved. The letter claiming responsibility for the violence also decried the legal system's handling of crimes by blacks against whites, particularly mentioning last year's slaying of Julie Love in Atlanta, a case never touched by the two men killed in the mid-December bombings. The letter, from a group calling itself Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System, said 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert S. Vance and Savannah attorney Robert Robinson were ``assassinated ... in reprisal for the atrocities inflicted upon Julie Love.'' The letter, which was sent to WAGA-TV in Atlanta and disclosed Thursday, said the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals must be shown that ``protecting the innocent warrants a higher court priority than granting the blacks' demand for white teachers for their children.'' The letter did not refer to specific cases. However, Vance was on the 11th Circuit panel that directed suburban Atlanta's DeKalb County school system this year to transfer about 120 veteran teachers from majority white schools to predominantly black ones in a long-running desegregation case there. A school desegregation case in Savannah also was before the 11th Circuit this year. Vance did not sit on the panel that heard the Savannah case, but Robinson had represented the NAACP in that suit. The letter threatened that ``two more prominent members of the NAACP shall be assassinated, using more sophisticated means'' as part of the reprisal for Ms. Love's death. A federal judge, an attorney and an NAACP officer will be killed, the letter added, ```anytime a black man rapes a white woman in Alabama, Florida or Georgia in the future.'' The Atlanta-based 11th Circuit hears federal appeals from those three states. Ms. Love, a white preschool fitness teacher, disappeared July 11, 1988, and her body was found last August. The search for her was highly publicized in the area, with ``Have You Seen Julie Love'' posters ubiquitous. Following the discovery of her body this year, two black men were arrested, one of whom has pleaded guilty to murder, rape, kidnapping and armed robbery. The other man is awaiting trial for murder. The DeKalb County school case dates back to 1969, when the system was first placed under a federal court order to desegregate. The 11th Circuit last year overturned a district judge's ruling that by 1988 DeKalb County had done its best to integrate the 73,000-student system. The appeals court's subsequent ruling that DeKalb must take further steps toward integration recently went before the Supreme Court, where the justices this month refused to intervene. In Savannah, a lengthy school desegregation case was decided in October when the 11th Circuit ruled that a ``magnet school'' plan offered by the school system was appropriate for integration. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which had argued that the plan still left many black students in segregated schools, has not yet said whether it will appeal.
